body.p: “Harlequin and Friar Bacon” is a British pantomime play from the collection of Glenn Hughes who used the collection in the 1930s and 1940s as a tool for research and teaching his students in the drama program at the University of Washington. It comes from a collection of over 3,000 plays, the majority British. It is likely that “Harlequin and Friar Bacon” belongs to the subset within the collection of works added from a single contributing collection, all of which were made as sales or gifts to the audience of a performance, mainly consisting of Christmas extravaganzas, pantomimes, and burlesques. Pantomimes are usually performed around Christmas and are comedies that often include slapstick humor, jokes, innuendos, magic, fairies, and gender reversal.

The focus of our edition of “Harlequin and Friar Bacon” is digitizing the original play to become accessible to actors and students who are interested in its content, whether that be for purposes of studying drama or gleaning an understanding of the content of historical plays. Pantomimes are still performed in the United States but with less frequency and popularity than in England, so the edition will also function to introduce actors to studies of plays on a global scale.

Our edition features a transcription which is intended to maintain as much of the original content as possible, including preserving the British spellings for words as opposed to Americanizing them. Racial slurs have been redacted and given note in the end notes if relevant to understanding the passage. Any italics and bold are preserved as they are displayed in the original play. In the original print, advertisements line the jacket and are interspersed throughout the text, which have not been preserved in this digital edition because it is not intended for viewing by audiences but by actors.

note.p: In English folklore, The Puck, also known as Goodfellows, are/is a domestic and nature sprite, demon, or fairy.

Oberon is a king of the fairies in medieval and Renaissance literature. He is best known as a character in William Shakespeare's play A Midsummer Night's Dream, in which he is King of the Fairies and spouse of Titania, Queen of the Fairies.

The Host is a character who plays a key role in and throughout Geoffrey Chaucer's The Canterbury Tales. He is the owner of the Tabard Inn in London, where the pilgrimage begins and he agrees to travel on the pilgrimage, and promises to judge both the tales the pilgrims tell, and disputes among the pilgrims.

Geoffrey Chaucer was an English poet, author, and civil servant best known for The Canterbury Tales. He has been called the "father of English literature", or, alternatively, the "father of English poetry".
John of Gaunt, Duke of Lancaster was an English royal prince, military leader, and statesman. He was the fourth son of King Edward III of England, and the father of King Henry IV.

div.head: SCENE V. – FRIAR BACON’S OBSERVATORY AT SUNNINGWELL NEAR OXFORD, AND DISTANT VIEW OF JOHN OF GAUNT‘ S CASTLE, BY SUNSET
div.stage: Over door of observatory, an inscription— ‘Friar Bacon, Licensed Dealer in Black Art.’ –Other boards about, such as ‘Conjuring Tricks provided, Evening Parties attended’ — ‘Dissolving Views lent out for the Evening’ — ‘Love-Philters made up’— ‘ Private Lessons in Parlour Magic.’ Expressive Music.
div.p: JOHN OF GAUNT enters, mysteriously. Enveloped in a large cloak, and attended by his ‘Squire, whom he dismisses as soon as he finds himself at the house of which he is in search—points to board, ‘Love Philters made up,’ and signifies that is the sort of thing he requires —knocks at door—House Pocus, the Friar’s servant, appears—john desires to see the learned Friar Bacon—man refuses—brings out board—‘The Friar is engaged in profound study’—John of Gaunt tries a bribe, and succeeds—the Friar is summoned, and appears with a large frying-pan, as if disturbed in frying a rasher of being discovered at this culinary operation, slaps man in, throws frying-pan after him, and attends to John of Gaunt, who takes him mysteriously down stage.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Before me, I behold, or I’m mistaken,
The famous necromancer, Friar Bacon!

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: Can I believe my eyes? It is—it arn’t—
Do I behold behind me John of Gaunt?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Hush! Mum! I come incog—would not be known—
You understand?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: I do !

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: Are we alone?

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: We are!

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: ‘Tis well! Now listen ;--in your trade,
I have heard, that curious potions can be made,
Which if a damsel drinks, she then is sure
To love the man she couldn’t bear before.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: You have heard aright. Here, Hocus Pocus, quick,
Bring me my magic drugs—I’ll show you a trick.

div.p: [Hocus Pocus appears from door, and receives instructions—goes off, and returns with large Brazier and large Bottle, which the Friar arranges on the stage—The assistant then brings in Packets, severally inscribed ’10,000 a year’ —‘Unlimited Pin Money’—‘Marriage Settlement’—‘A new Bonnet every Week’—these are successively put into the Bottle.
These various things united—mark the list—
I never knew a woman to resist.
[Red Fire is kindled below, and the Friar then draws a Phial forth from the Bottle. One trial proves the fact: its worth the heeding,
Though some might call this quite a phial proceeding.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: I’ll give the draft at once.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: That’s all right—thank yer—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: We’ll talk of that anon. Now, Friar, learn,
To-day, in honor of my safe return,
We give a sumptuous spread—it there you walk,
You are sure to find a friendly knife and fork—
This ticket will admit you to the fete.
And there’s a Tournament, if you like to wait.

sp.speaker: Friar.
sp.l: You very good, but there’s a small amount—
Consoling himself.
Well, I’ll do some business on my own account.

div.p: [Friar calls on Hocus Pocus, who has cleared off the other articles whilst the Friar puts on clean collar, and goes through toilet business, and a Box is brought on, labelled ‘Conjuring Tricks.’ which the Friar takes and goes off with, followed by Hocus Pocus, bearing a Box, labelled ‘Magic Lantern.’—Excunt(Latin)—scene closes.

div.head: SCENE VI.—GOTHIC CORRIDOR, LEADING TO BANQUETING ROOM.
div.p: Lively Music. –The Retainers and Servants of John of Gaunt cross the stage, bearing the customary Pantomimic, Viands for the Banquet—after they have crossed, JOHN OF GAUNT enters, with ROSE, whom he drags on—he renews his protestations- she repulses him—CHAUCER, with his lance in his hand, appears at the back, through sliding panel—he observes them—Servant crosses with Goblet of Wine on a tray, which Gaunt takes—unseen by Rose, he turns into it the contents of the phial—offers it to Rose—Chaucer stepping forward at the moment touches it with his Lance, and the contents of the goblet blaze up and are gone.—Through being over the flame, John of Gaunt is seized with a sudden fit of sneezing.—In the confusion, Chaucer escapes with Rose—Servants return—John wreaks his vengeance upon them—Herald enters, with Trumpet and Scroll, labelled
‘THE TOURNAMENT HAS COMMENCED’
All rush off—and scene draws, discovering

div.head: SCENE VII.—THE COURT-YARD OF JOHN OF GAUNT’S CASTLE.
div.p: Pavilion at back—The Lists are formed—The Galleries are filled with spectators—Stage full at the sides, and only the centre kept clear for the Combatants—Herald blows a trumpet—Chaucer enters with Rose, and signifies he is confident of success—Large Scroll unfolded, ‘The Victor may claims any Prize in the Lists.’—JOHN OF GAUNT enters and flings down large gauntlet into the arena—Chaucer picks it up, and challenges John of Gaunt, who first of all produces sword and shield—These are no sooner touched by the Magic Lance than the shield expands into a large bouquet of Roses, and the sword opens into a large Fan—John of Gaunt gives them to a Lady of the Court, and then commences a Comic Combat with lances, which ends in the discomfiture of John of Gaunt.—Chaucer goes to the Pavilion and leads Rose down.

sp.speaker: Chaucer.
sp.l: Be witness all—this is the prize I choose.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.l: A slight mistake—that maiden I refuse.
What ho, there! Seize the caitiff!—now I’m calmer.
sp.p: [Retainers seize Chaucer, whilst John of Gaunt snatches the lamp.
sp.l: I have his charms, and now I’ll have his charmer.

sp.speaker: Chaucer.
sp.l: Then thus on Robin Goodfellow I call.

div.p: Chord—and instantaneous change to

div.head: SCENE VIII.—THE TRANSPARENT REALMS OF ILLUTIONS, IN THE REGIONS OF POETRY.
div.p: All the Fairies discovered.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Behold our Fairy Court assembled all.
This lady fair, through no one did imagine it,
Is in reality Miss Rose Plantagenet.
Woo’d by the poet in her humble guise,
He now has fairly won her for his prize.
To aid the promised revels of to-night,
As Columbine, henceforth the world delight.
You, whose poetic feet we nimble see,
As Harlequin, her lover still shall be

div.p: Enter IMAGINATION.

sp.speaker: Imagination.
sp.l: To do without me you were much mistaken,
From all this change, you shall not save your Bacon.
So, Friar, stand forth, these robes abandon soon,
And only have a band on Pantaloon.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: John of Gaunt escape? In well-know lingo
I’ll swear he still shall have more thumps, by jingo.
So, change to Clown—your fame has spread afar—
And charm each ear with jocund ‘Here we are.;’
[To Harlequin,] Your magic lance, sir, this will supersede;
But still ‘twill answer in the hour of need. [Gives bat.

sp.speaker: Imagination.
sp.l: Yet one word more—behold this Christmas Tree,
Shall this appear and we no blossom see?
Not so! Receive this little augmentation
Of all these ‘pleasures of Imagination!’

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.l: Now, then, away, once more, to quote the poet,
In all your merriment be wise—

sp.speaker: Imagination.
sp.l: And go it.

div.head: Footnote Page
div.p: THE TABARD.—As the Borough High Street was formerly the great passage into a great part of the kingdom to and from the capital, it was well furnished with inns, the above having been immortalized by Chaucer. The sign is now perverted into ‘The Talbot.’ It originally was ‘The Tabard,’ so called from the sign, a sleeveless coat open on both sides, with a square collar and winged at the shoulders: worn by persons of rank in the wars, with their arms painted on them, that they might be known. The use of this coat is now transferred to the heralds. This was the rendezvous of the jolly pilgrims who formed the group which our ‘father of poetry’ describes sallying out to pay their devotions to the great saint, Thomas a Beckett, whose shrine, for a long time, surperseded almost every other, being resorted to down to the Reformation by pilgrims from every part of Christendom. The sign was changed from the ‘Tabard’ to the ‘Talbot,’ about the year 1676. The following inscription used to appear on the frieze of the beams which hung across the road, and from the centre of which the sign was suspended.—‘This is the inn where Sir Jeffery Chaucer and the nine-and -twenty pilgrims lay, in their journey to Canterbury, anno 1383.
